title: Installation
content:
Getting Burner up and running on a development machine is a pretty quick process. The very first step is to configure your basic site settings, which are located in app/config/development/config.php. The most important config option to pay attention to at this time is the base_url, which should be set to the root URL of your website:

// Application's Base URL (including trailing slash)
Config::set('base_url', 'localhost:8888/burner-site/');

Next, the MySQL settings need to be configured. These can be found in app/config/development/db.php:

Config::set('database',array(
	
	'host'=>'localhost',
	'username'=>'root',
	'password'=>'root',
	'database'=>'burner_site'
	
));

Lastly, run the following commands from the terminal. This will generate unique hash settings for authentication; create the MySQL tables for the user, group, and membership models; create the admin group if it doesn't exist; and it will prompt you to create an admin user.

cd path/to/directory/containing/index.php
php index.php generate_hash_secret development
php index.php install

For more information on these commands, please either see their respective documentation pages or use the help command like so:

php index.php help generate_hash_secret
php index.php help install

title: Models Overview
content:
Models make up the heart and soul of every Burner application. In Burner, models are used to interface with the database in an object-oriented fashion. Each model represents a single table in the database. Additionally, models tell Burner how data can be managed in the admin control panel.

Defining Models

To define a new model, create a PHP file in the app/model folder with the name of the model that you want (all lowercase file name). For the sake of example, we'll create a model named Article, so the file will be app/model/article.php. Now create a class in this file which extends the base model:

<?php

namespace App\Model;

class Article extends \Core\Model\Base {

}

The next step is to define columns for the model. This is done by adding properties to the class, which have doc comments that define their data types by using the special @option syntax.

class Article extends \Core\Model\Base {

    /**
     * @option type = Varchar
     * @option length = 100
     * @option required = The title field is required.
     */
    public $title;

    /**
     * @option type = Text
     * @option required = The content field is required.
     */
    public $content;

}

After the model is defined, the table can be created in the database by using the create command from the terminal.

php index.php create article

If you would like to see the table creation SQL before actually creating it, then use the sql command.

php index.php sql article

Model tables can also be dropped by using the drop command.

php index.php drop article

There are more terminal commands available for use as well, so be sure to check out the CLI Commands section of the guides documentation.

Enabling For The Admin

Making it so that model data can be managed in the admin is just a matter of adding the model name to the correct configuration option. To add the article model, just open up app/config/development/config.php and change the appropriate option, like so:

Config::set('admin_models', array(
	'Users' => array('user', 'group', 'membership'),
	'Some Category' => array('article')
));

Model API

Once a model has been created, it can be used from within any part of your application in order to query the database. The API covers everything from table creation to complex select queries.

// Select
$results = \App\Model\Article::select()->where('title', '=', 'Awesome')->fetch();

// Insert
$a = new \App\Model\Article();
$a->title = 'Cool';
$a->content = 'Yup.';
$id = $a->save();

// Drop table
\App\Model\Article::drop_table();

For more complete examples please refer to the remainder of the model guides.

title: CLI Overview
content:
Burner CMS comes bundled with a collection of useful commands, which are runnable via the terminal. It's also easy to define your own custom terminal commands. Burner's bundled commands can be found in the burner/command directory.

Defining Commands

Commands are just PHP classes which have the help() and run() methods. To create a command, just make a new PHP file in the app/command directory. The file name should be exactly the same as the class name, except all lowercase. So for a command with the class name of Foo, the file path (relative to index.php) would be app/command/foo.php. The content of this file might look something like this:

<?php

namespace App\Command;

class Foo {

    public function help() {
        echo "Useful information about the command.\n\n";
    }

    public function run($name) {
        echo "Hello, $name!\n\n";
    }

}

This command could then be run from the terminal like so:

php index.php foo Bob

Which would output the following:

Hello, Bob!\n\n

And the help message could be displayed by running the help command:

php index.php help foo

title: CLI Help Command
content:
The help command displays (hopefully) helpful documentation for other commands. Example usage and output:

php index.php help sql
sql <model> [, <model>, ... ]

Description:
    Generates SQL for a given model(s). Requires database connection.

title: CLI SQL Command
content:
The SQL command outputs MySQL CREATE TABLE syntax for the given models. Useful for seeing what MySQL Burner's ORM is generating under the hood. Example usage and output:

php index.php sql user
CREATE TABLE `user`(
`id` INT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
PRIMARY KEY(`id`),
`email` VARCHAR(100),
`password` CHAR(128)
) ENGINE = InnoDB;

title: CLI Create Command
content:
The create command generates and runs MySQL CREATE TABLE syntax for the given models. Example usage:

php index.php create user

title: CLI Drop Command
content:
The drop command generates and runs MySQL DROP TABLE syntax for the given models. Example usage:

php index.php drop user

title: CLI Sync Command
content:
The sync command drops and then recreates the MySQL tables for the given models. Useful for making quick model changes in development environments. Example usage:

php index.php sync user

Note: MySQL tables are dropped and then recreated when running this command. They are not altered. This means that any data stored in the given models will be lost.

title: CLI Install Command
content:
Creates MySQL tables for the User, Group, and Membership models if they don't already exist; creates 'admin' group if it doesn't exist; and prompts you to create an admin user. Example usage:

php index.php install

Note: Only works with MultipleGroups auth plugin (which is the default). Running after insert error shouldn't mess up existing data.

title: CLI Generate Hash Command
content:
Creates a random string and sets it to 'hash_secret' configuration option, which is used for hashing passwords. Example usage:

php index.php generate_hash_secret development

Note: This will overwrite the app/config/<config>/hash.php file.

title: CLI Export JSON Command
content:
Exports the contents of the MySQL table for a model to a JSON formatted file. Example usage:

php index.php export_json user outfile.json

title: CLI Import JSON Command
content:
Imports the contents of a JSON formatted file to the MySQL table of the specified model. Example usage:

php index.php import_json user infile.json

title: CLI Alter Add Command
content:
Adds a column to the MySQL table of the specified model. Column must be defined in the model for this to work.

php index.php alter_add user some_unsynced_column

Note: Always make backups of important data before running this command!

title: CLI Create Controller Command
content:
Creates a controller file with the specified controller class name. Example usage:

php index.php create_controller Foo

This would create a controller file at app/controller/foo.php with the following content:

<?php

namespace App\Controller;

class Foo extends \Core\Controller\Base {

}

Note: Make sure to use the correct capitalization for the class name while using this command. For example, bar would be incorrect, but Bar would be fine.

title: CLI Create Model Command
content:
Creates a model file with the specified model class name. Example usage:

php index.php create_model Foo

This would create a model file at app/model/foo.php with the following content:

<?php

namespace App\Model;

class Foo extends \Core\Model\Base {

}

Note: Make sure to use the correct capitalization for the class name while using this command. For example, bar would be incorrect, but Bar would be fine.

title: Autoloading
content:
Burner CMS uses a PHP feature known as autoloading to automatically include class files. To determine which files are loaded for which classes, Burner follows the PSR-0 standard pretty closely, but with some changes.

For anyone new to the concept of autoloading, it's like this: you can use classes without having to manually include the class files yourself. Burner uses the namespace and class name to find and include the class file automatically for you.

Examples

Here's a few examples of classes and which files are loaded for them:

  • • \Foo maps to foo.php
  • • \App\Foo maps to app/foo.php
  • • \App\Model\Foo maps to app/model/foo.php
  • • \App\Model\Foo_Bar maps to app/model/foo/bar.php
  • • \App\Model\Foo_Bar\Baz maps to app/model/foo_bar/baz.php
  • • \App\Controller\Baz maps to app/controller/baz.php
  • • \App\Vendor\Admin\Controller\Admin maps to app/vendor/admin/controller/admin.php

Exceptions

As stated above, there are exceptions to how Burner follows the PSR-0 standard. Here they are:

  • • File and directory names are always completely lowercase.
  • • \Core\<class> maps to burner/<class>.php
  • • \Library\<class> maps to burner/library/<class>.php
  • • \Column\<class> maps to burner/column/<class>.php

Customizations

Because 3rd-party PHP libraries come in a wide variety of class naming schemes, Burner allows you to specify additional autoloading rules. Here's an example:

\Core\Autoload::set('/^Awesome/', function($class_name) {

    $path = str_replace('_', '/', $class_name);
    return "awesome-library/$path.php";

});

Note: When used, this feature does add overhead to class autoloading, so use it sparingly. If you only need to load 3rd-party classes in one place, then consider placing this config code right before you need to load those 3rd-party classes. However, if you need to use those 3rd-party classes in many places, then app/config/<configuration>/config.php might be a better place for this config code.

title: Start Here
content: The best way to learn how to use Burner CMS is to just read through all of the guides in The Basics category. Start with the installation guide, skim over the guides which are designed to be overviews of important topics, and then go through the photo gallery tutorial. After that, then you should have a good enough idea of how Burner works to be able to understand the other guide categories.

title: Requirements
content:
A few things are required to install and run Burner CMS:

  • • Apache with Mod Rewrite enabled
  • • PHP 5.3 of higher
  • • MySQL

Highly Recommended

Access to the PHP command line interface is highly recommended, because it allows you to use all of Burner's helpful CLI development tools. Not sure if you have access? If you can get this command to run successfully from your terminal, then you should be all set:

php --version

If your web host doesn't support command line access, then we would highly recommend that you check out Linode. It's a very affordable and solid VPS hosting service. And no, we aren't getting paid to say this.
